data.title: Cheat Sheet
data.description: Use this cheat sheet to brush up on your Linux commands and for all those Linux commands you can't quite remember!

data.title: General
data.description: General commands

userActivity.Value: /lib - "c" libraries used by programs and kernel
/usr - user programs and utilities (binaries, docs, libraries, include files, etc.)
/bin - OS essential binaries (ls, cp, mv, etc.)
/etc - system configuration files, includes startup scripts
/mnt - mount point for external file systems
/var - variable data (mail and printer spools, log files, lock files, etc.)

userActivity.Value: Running multple antivirus software can cause issues.  You will need to remove other antivirus software before installing MDE.

One method for identifying other antivirus software is to look for the process.  The below command will show all processes with 'av' in the name.  If you see other antivirus software, you will need to remove it before installing MDE.

data.title: Performance Monitoring
data.description: General performance monitoring for Linux.

data.title: System Load Monitoring
data.description: Monitor the system load to understand the demand on system resources.

userActivity.Value: uptime  gives a one line display of the following information.  The current time, how long the system has been running, how many users are currently logged on, and the system load  averages for the past 1, 5, and 15 minutes.

backgroundActivity.Value: The output shows the current system load averages for the past 1, 5, and 15 minutes.

userActivity.Value: free  displays  the  total  amount of free and used physical and swap memory in the system, as well as the buffers and caches used by the kernel.

antivirus-engine-pool-content         Monitor the content for all antivirus engine core pools content

  real-time-protection-statistics       Display real-time protection resource usage statistics
  event-provider-statistics             Display event provider internal statistics
  behavior-monitoring-statistics        Display behavior monitoring resource usage statistics
  hot-event-sources                     Monitor hot event sources (preview feature)
  ebpf-statistics                       Display ebpf internal statistics
  upload                                Generate and submit support log to Microsoft

The command will run indefinitely until you stop it with CTRL+C.

data.title: Configure MDATP
data.description: Configure MDATP

userActivity.Value: Make sure you have the correct permissions and licenses. You will need to be a Global Administrator or Security Administrator to access this page.
Then Select Linux Server from the drop list of operating systems.

tasks.title: Optional - Copy the onboarding script to the Linux server

userActivity.Value: Optional - Copy the onboarding script to the Linux server
If you are running Windows with Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) you can copy the onboarding script to the Linux server using the following command.
The above command is using a certificate to authenitcate to the Linux server. You can also use a username and password.
The file copied is stored in the home directory of the user you are authenticating as.
From the folder where you have copied the onboarding script.
Let's check the current org_id configuration of the MDE for Linux agent.

troubleshooting_mode                        : false
Note the org_id is now populated and healthy is true.
You can also check the Security Portal to see if the device is reporting in. https://security.microsoft.com/machines

data.title: RHEL iptables
data.description: Use the guide to troubleshoot issues with MDE connectivity to the Microsoft cloud service endpoints. We will use iptables to block and then allow outbound traffic to the MDE endpoints so we can see what errors and logs occur.

data.title: Check iptables rules
data.description: Allow MDE to communicate with the Microsoft cloud service endpoints.

backgroundActivity.Value: The output shows the current iptables rules. The -S option is used to list the rules in a format that can be used as input to iptables-restore.

-P INPUT ACCEPT
-P FORWARD ACCEPT
-P OUTPUT ACCEPT
The above output shows that the default policy for the INPUT, FORWARD and OUTPUT chains is ACCEPT.

data.title: Optional: Block outbound traffic
data.description: Block all outbound traffic.

userActivity.Value: Test outbound connection with curl works successfully

backgroundActivity.Value:
301 Moved

The document has moved here.

userActivity.Value: sudo iptables -A OUTPUT -p tcp -m multiport --dport 80,443 -j REJECT

backgroundActivity.Value: Our iptables rule was applied, we can check by viewing the rules again.

Chain INPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain FORWARD (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain OUTPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination
REJECT     tcp  --  anywhere             anywhere             multiport dports http,https reject-with icmp-port-unreachable
Any subsequent curl commands on port 80 and 443 will fail.

userActivity.Value: Test outbound connection with curl is blocked successfully

backgroundActivity.Value: curl: (28) Failed to connect to google.com port 80: Connection timed out
The above output shows that the connection timed out, which means the outbound traffic was blocked.

userActivity.Value: Allow outbound traffic to MDE endpoints
From our test above we can see which endpoints are blocked.

You should always refer to the official documentation for the latest list of endpoints. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/microsoft-defender-endpoint-linux?view=o365-worldwide#network-connections
For the purpose of this lab we will allow only the endpoints identified in the previous step.
Allow outbound traffic to the Microsoft cloud service endpoints.
This is for demonstration purposes only. Using domain/host name in iptables rules is not recommended. You should always use IP addresses.

When iptables applies to rule above  it evaluates the domain name and resolves it to an IP address. If the IP address changes, the rule will no longer work. You will need to update the rule with the new IP address.
If we perform multiple nslookups against nf.smartscreen.microsoft.com we can see that the IP address changes.

data.title: Envrionment Setup
data.description: Get the environment ready for MDE for Linux on Ubuntu

userActivity.Value: Install curl if it isn't installed yet

Curl  is  a  tool  to  transfer data from or to a server, using one of the supported protocols (DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS,  LDAP,  LDAPS,  POP3,  POP3S,  RTMP, RTSP,  SCP,  SFTP,  SMB,  SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET and TFTP). The command is designed to work without user interaction.
Install libplist-utils if it isn't installed yet
This package contains tools to convert Apple property list files from binary to XML and vice-versa.
Each Linux distrobution has a different package manager. For example, Ubuntu uses apt-get, while SUSE uses zypper.

data.title: Configure MDATP
data.description: Configure MDATP

userActivity.Value: Make sure you have the correct permissions and licenses. You will need to be a Global Administrator or Security Administrator to access this page.

tasks.title: Optional - Copy the onboarding script to the Linux server

userActivity.Value: Optional - Copy the onboarding script to the Linux server
If you are running Windows with Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) you can copy the onboarding script to the Linux server using the following command.
The above command is using a certificate to authenitcate to the Linux server. You can also use a username and password.
The file copied is stored in the home directory of the user you are authenticating as.
Install unzip if not already installed.
